title: Reading Comprehension: Main Idea and Details

vocab.definition: What a piece of writing is mostly about.
Facts, examples, or information that explain or support the main idea.
A short statement of the most important points of a text.
Text information that helps prove or support the main idea.
A sentence that often states the main idea of a paragraph.

teachingNotes: Teach students to look for the 'who' or 'what' the text is about and what the most important thing about that 'who' or 'what' is. Use graphic organizers to visually separate the main idea from the details.

sample.question: After reading a short paragraph, what is the main idea?
expectedAny: the central point of the paragraph
what the text is mostly about

sample.question: Which detail from the text best supports the main idea that dogs are helpful animals?
expectedAny: a specific example of a dog helping someone
a fact that shows dogs help

sample.question: What is this passage mostly about?
Which sentence from the text best summarizes the entire passage?
expectedAny: the sentence that captures the main idea
a sentence that tells the big idea

sample.question: Find three details in the text that support the main idea.
expectedAny: three specific facts or examples from the text

sample.question: Based on the main idea, what would be another good title for this passage?
expectedAny: a title that reflects the main idea
a title that matches the big idea
a clear title about the topic

sample.question: Which of these facts from the text does not belong with the main idea?
expectedAny: a detail that does not support the main idea

truefalse.question: The main idea of a text tells what it is mostly about.
Supporting details are small pieces of information that explain more about the main idea.
Every sentence in a paragraph is equally important.
The main idea is always the very first sentence of a paragraph.
Details give specific information, like facts, reasons, or examples.
A summary should include every single detail from the text.
The title of a book or article often gives a clue about the main idea.

multiplechoice.question: The main idea is the ___ point of the text.
A good title for a text is usually ___.
choices: clear and related to the main idea
expectedAny: clear and related to the main idea
a clear title about the main idea
a title that matches the topic

multiplechoice.question: To find the main idea, a good reader looks for ___.
choices: ideas that are repeated or talked about the most
expectedAny: ideas that are repeated or talked about the most
what is talked about the most

multiplechoice.question: Details in a well-written paragraph should always ___.
A summary is a ___ retelling of the main points.
A topic sentence is a sentence that often ___.
choices: states the main idea of a paragraph
expectedAny: states the main idea of a paragraph

fillintheblank.question: The ___ idea tells what the text is mostly about.
Supporting ___ give more information and examples about the main idea.
A ___ is a short retelling of the most important points.
The ___ of a passage often gives a clue to the main idea.
Irrelevant details are ones that do not ___ to the main idea.
Authors use facts, examples, and reasons as ___ to support their main idea.
Often, each paragraph in a text has its own ___ idea.

shortanswer.question: What is a good strategy to find the main idea of a text?
expectedAny: look for ideas repeated the most
summarize the paragraph in your own words

shortanswer.question: Explain the difference between a main idea and a supporting detail.
expectedAny: main idea is the big point; details support it
main idea is what it's mostly about; details tell more
details are facts/examples that explain the main idea
main idea is the topic; details give information

shortanswer.question: Why are supporting details important in a text?
expectedAny: they help explain the main idea clearly

shortanswer.question: How do you write a good summary of a paragraph?
expectedAny: identify main idea and key details
retell only the most important points
use your own words and be brief
say the big idea and key facts

shortanswer.question: What makes a good title for a story or article?
expectedAny: tells what the text is about

shortanswer.question: Give an example of a main idea with three supporting details.
expectedAny: Main Idea: Dogs make good pets. Details: They are loyal; they can be trained; they are playful.
Main Idea: Exercise is healthy. Details: strengthens your heart; builds muscles; boosts energy.
Main Idea: Reading helps you learn. Details: teaches new words; grows knowledge; improves focus.
any main idea with three supporting facts

shortanswer.question: How can you tell if a detail is important or just interesting?
expectedAny: important details explain or prove the main idea
ask if it supports the main idea
interesting details do not help explain the main idea
does it relate to the main idea
